Lexington County School District Three now has applications available for the Families Helping Families Christmas assistance program. The program, which is an initiative of the Palmetto Project, provides assistance to thousands of families in the Midlands each year who are in need of food, clothing and Christmas gifts for children.

Lexington Three has 25 applications that are available to families on a first come, first served basis. Anyone who would like to complete a form can contact Lexington Three’s social worker, Lindsey Zemla, via email (lzemla@lex3.org) or phone (803-604-7845). Efforts will be made to accommodate applicants who would like to complete the applications virtually amidst the COVID-19 pandemic.

All applications are due back by no later than October 1st.

The Lexington County School District Three Board of Trustees approved Michelle Maroney as the new Instructional Coordinator of B-L Primary School at its meeting on Tuesday, August 11th. Ms. Maroney has worked at B-L Primary School for the past three years, first as a second grade teacher and then as the school’s literacy coach. In 2019, she was named as the school’s Teacher of the Year.

Ms. Maroney holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Early Childhood Education from Toccoa Falls College and a Master of Education degree in Administration and Supervision from Clemson University. In her spare time, she enjoys spending time with her family, including her six-year-old daughter, Grace, reading and knitting.

Ms. Maroney said the best thing about working in Lexington School District Three is that you are working with a family. “We are entering some uncertain times, but we are conquering the challenges together, one day at a time.”

Congratulations!

Lexington County School District Three is excited to announce that the B-L High School Class of 2021's Commencement Ceremony will be held on Saturday, June 12, 2021 at 9 am in Panther Stadium.

Lexington Three made the decision to move the graduation ceremony from Friday night to Saturday morning in an effort to preserve the longstanding tradition of graduates receiving their diplomas on the high school football field.

The reasoning behind this is that it's less likely for storms to develop during the morning hours as opposed to evenings during the summer months. In addition, the summertime heat should be less oppressive in the morning, giving our elderly guests and those with underlying health conditions a better opportunity to attend and support our seniors.

Goooooooooooooo Panthers!

Ke’Shoun Williams, a 2020 graduate of Batesburg-Leesville High School, has been named as a top ten finalist for the inaugural Bridge Builder Excellence Award (BBEA). This award, which is being presented by the South Carolina Football Hall of Fame, recognizes high school football players for their accomplishments in the community, in the classroom and on the field. Did You Know?

A complete count of SC residents in the US Census will drive local funding allocations for SCHOOLS, healthcare, disaster response, and more than 50 other federal programs for the next 10 years.

Census data is used to support economic development and the installation of broadband internet (which is desperately needed in our rural part of the county).

If just 100 people are not counted in this year's census, our state is missing out on approximately $3,000,000 over the next 10 years that could have been used on any of the above-mentioned efforts.

As part of today's "Census Day of Action Challenge," we encourage you to fill out your US Census form to support our Panther students and B-L community.

www.my2020census.gov

On Tuesday, May 26th, B-L High School will find out if it has been named Palmetto's Finest during a broadcast on the local SCETV PBS station.

Tune in at 1 pm for the big announcement!

B-L High School is one of three statewide finalists vying for the prestigious title. The school was chosen to enter the final round of the competition following a rigorous 20-page application process and an extensive on-campus evaluation by the Palmetto’s Finest Awards Committee back in November. The school underwent its final on-campus evaluation by the Palmetto's Finest Committee earlier this year.

BLHS is already a winner in our books, but we've got our fingers crossed for them. Please join us in sending them well-wishes!

We are PANTHER PROUD!

Lexington County School District Three’s students joined millions of their peers from across the country on Monday, March 2nd to celebrate the National Education Association’s (NEA) Read Across America Day. Read Across America Day is the nation’s largest celebration of reading, with around 45 million people, both young and old, picking up a book to read. The day is always held on March 2nd, which is the birthday of the legendary children’s book author Dr. Seuss.

In Lexington Three, several schools decided to make the reading celebrations last all week. From hat day and crazy sock day to dress-up days that took students on a figurative journey across America with themes such as the “Wild, Wild West,” the ultimate goal of the week was to help children discover the joys of literacy and foster their love of reading. District administrators even got in on the fun by reading their favorite books to classes at Batesburg-Leesville Elementary School.

We shared this video a few weeks ago, but one of our staff members wrote a poem to go along with it and WOW IS ALL WE CAN SAY.

Thank you, Jennifer Richardson, for writing this awesome poem!
Thank you, Ashley Fort, for narrating it!

We love our B-L Panthers!

(The poem can also be found below.)

Once upon a time, in a town so far and dear.
There was a small school, whose students had no fear.
For they were mighty Panthers, who stood tall and proud.
And never cowered down in the face of a crowd.
They worked hard in school each day, and as the years went by.
They realized their school had given them the power to try.
Many years went by, and students grew up tall.
But then they had children, who returned when they were small.
For the love of the Panther Nation is something that is strong.
And with the roar of a B-L Panther, you cannot go wrong.
Happy Birthday B-L Panthers, for this is your 100th year.
And with students just like these, we have nothing to ever fear.
